newsitem.title: UK: OFT completes BA/American alliance study.
newsitem.headline: OFT completes BA/American alliance study.

text.p: Britain's Office of Fair Trading (OFT) said on Tuesday it had completed a three-month competition investigation into the proposed alliance between British Airways Plc and American Airlines, a unit of AMR Corp, and had forwarded its review to the trade ministry.
"I can confirm that the papers left for the Department of Trade today," an OFT spokeswoman told Reuters.
Trade minister Ian Lang will use the OFT's advice in deciding whether or not the controversial alliance should be referred to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission for a full monopolies probe.
Industry sources, who predicted that the OFT would complete its study this week, have said they do not expect Lang to announce his verdict before next week.
Recent media and industry speculation has suggested that Lang will give the alliance qualified clearance, provided that BA's home hub of London Heathrow is opened up to competition.
BA and American's plans have attracted fierce criticism from rival airlines as well as consumer groups and travel agents, who say the alliance will dominate the London trans-Atlantic market.
Under the link-up, BA intends to coordinate its 244 weekly flights from Britain to 22 U.S. destinations with all American's 238 flights from seven US airports to 12 European destinations.
They would also combine their frequent flyer programmes and share flight booking codes to promote their connecting flights on computer reservation systems, and combine cargo businesses.

BA and American argue their deal will lead to greater competition on British transatlantic routes because it will only go ahead if Britain and the U.S. liberalise the market with an "open skies" trade pact.
At the same time they say they need to link to compete against rival alliances such as that between United Airlines and Germany's Lufthansa for all-important transfer traffic.

"Open skies" talks between government negotiators, which need to succeed before Washington can consider giving the plan much-needed anti-trust immunity, broke down last month but there has been strong industry speculation that they will be reopened shortly, with some concessions, once the OFT verdict is known.
